content.card_other: Branch of physics dealing with heat, work, temperature, and energy. Studies energy transformations and relationship between macroscopic properties of systems. Based on four fundamental laws.
Region of space under study separated from surroundings by boundary. Open: exchanges matter and energy. Closed: exchanges energy only. Isolated: exchanges neither.
Measure of average kinetic energy of molecules. Determines direction of heat flow (hot to cold). SI unit: kelvin (K). Absolute zero (0 K = -273.15°C) is lowest possible temperature.
Energy transferred between systems due to temperature difference. Flows from high to low temperature. Not a state function - depends on process. SI unit: joule. Symbol: Q.
Total energy of all molecules in system (kinetic + potential). State function - depends only on current state, not path. For ideal gas, depends only on temperature. Symbol: U.
Energy transfer by means other than heat. Can be mechanical (PV work), electrical, etc. Positive when done by system (expansion). Negative when done on system (compression).
Energy conservation: change in internal energy equals heat added minus work done by system: ΔU = Q - W. Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
Path taken by system from one state to another. Different processes transfer energy differently. Common types: isothermal, adiabatic, isobaric, isochoric.
Process at constant temperature (ΔT = 0). For ideal gas: PV = constant (Boyle's law). Internal energy constant (ΔU = 0), so Q = W. Slow process allowing heat exchange.
Process with no heat transfer (Q = 0). System thermally insulated. ΔU = -W. For ideal gas: PVᵞ = constant. Temperature changes. Faster than isothermal. Example: rapid compression/expansion.
Process at constant pressure (ΔP = 0). V/T = constant (Charles's law). Work done = PΔV. Common in atmospheric processes and engines with pistons.
Process at constant volume (ΔV = 0). P/T = constant (Gay-Lussac's law). No work done (W = 0), so ΔU = Q. Heat added directly increases internal energy.
Heat required to raise temperature of unit mass by 1°C (or 1 K). Depends on material. SI unit: J/(kg·K). Symbol: c. Water has high specific heat (4186 J/(kg·K)).
Heat required to raise temperature of one mole by 1 K. Two values for gases: Cₚ (constant pressure) and Cᵥ (constant volume). Cₚ > Cᵥ because work done in expansion.
Heat required for phase change at constant temperature. Latent heat of fusion: solid ↔ liquid. Latent heat of vaporization: liquid ↔ gas. No temperature change during phase transition.
Theoretical gas with no intermolecular forces and negligible molecular volume. Obeys ideal gas law: PV = nRT. Good approximation for real gases at low pressure and high temperature.
Equation of state relating pressure, volume, temperature, and amount: PV = nRT. R = 8.314 J/(mol·K) is universal gas constant. Combines Boyle's, Charles's, and Avogadro's laws.

Microscopic model explaining gas behavior. Assumptions: large number of molecules in random motion, elastic collisions, negligible molecular size, no intermolecular forces. Relates macroscopic properties to molecular motion.
Mean kinetic energy of gas molecules directly proportional to absolute temperature: KE_avg = (3/2)kT. All gases at same temperature have same average KE per molecule.
Square root of average of squared speeds of molecules. Measure of typical molecular speed. Proportional to √T and inversely proportional to √M. Lighter molecules move faster at given temperature.

Device converting heat into work. Operates in cycles between hot and cold reservoirs. Takes heat from hot reservoir, does work, rejects remaining heat to cold reservoir. Examples: steam engine, car engine.
Ratio of work output to heat input: η = W/Qₕ = 1 - Qc/Qₕ. Always less than 100% (second law). Maximum efficiency is Carnot efficiency. Improved by increasing temperature difference.
Ideal reversible heat engine operating between two temperatures. Maximum possible efficiency for given temperature limits: η_c = 1 - Tc/Tₕ. Real engines less efficient. Sets theoretical upper limit.
Theoretical reversible cycle with four processes: isothermal expansion, adiabatic expansion, isothermal compression, adiabatic compression. Most efficient cycle possible between two temperatures.
Heat naturally flows from hot to cold, not reverse (Clausius). No engine can be 100% efficient (Kelvin-Planck). Entropy of isolated system never decreases. Defines arrow of time.
Measure of disorder or randomness in system. State function. Increases in spontaneous processes. For reversible process at constant T: ΔS = Q/T. Universe's entropy always increases.

Heat engine operating in reverse. Transfers heat from cold to hot reservoir using external work. Cannot work without work input (violates second law otherwise). Examples: refrigerator, air conditioner.
For refrigerator: ratio of heat removed from cold reservoir to work input: COP = Qc/W. Can be greater than 1. Higher COP means more efficient. For heat pump: (Qₕ/W).
If A and B are each in thermal equilibrium with C, then A and B are in thermal equilibrium with each other. Establishes concept of temperature. Foundation for thermometry.
Entropy of perfect crystal at absolute zero is zero. Absolute zero (0 K) is unattainable - would require infinite steps. Provides reference point for entropy calculations.

Reversible: can be reversed without change in universe. Ideal, infinitely slow, no entropy increase. Irreversible: cannot be reversed without changes. All real processes irreversible due to friction, heat loss.
